I can't believe you didn't mention its use in narcolepsy even once. It's really disappointing. I have narcolepsy w/ cataplexy, and CNS stimulants (like Adderall, Ritalin, Dexedrine, and yes, even Desoxyn sometimes) are very important in treating narcolepsy (and Idiopathic Hypersomnia).

If you have narcolepsy or IH, the negatives of CNS stimulants are a bit less important... because having uncontrolled narcolepsy is much more dangerous! Multiple studies have shown that people with narcolepsy are more likely to die from accidents.

Narcolepsy also causes another dangerous symptom: cataplexy, a sudden loss of muscle tone that is triggered by strong emotions, often positive ones. Cataplectic attacks can range from just mild face weakness, to head drops, and even to full-body collapses– all while still maintaining full consciousness.

Narcolepsy and cataplexy are treated with another very surprising and "controversial" drug: sodium oxybate, also known as GHB. Yes, that GHB. Despite the "street drug" reputation and potential for abuse, the brand-name drugs (Xyrem & Xywav) are still first-line treatments for narcolepsy and cataplexy, because in the worst circumstances, this disorder can absolutely kill you.

Me (ADHD) on the other hand, has to create a LOT of noise and distract other people trying to stimulate myself by kicking, chewing, fiddling, and it’s not comfortable for me and the people around me. My other option is to suck it all up except it’s incredibly difficult to focus on one sentence that way. My solution: stimulant medication. It stimulates my brain so I don’t have to distract other people or suffer trying to give myself the stimulation I desperately crave. The fact everyone’s out here going “tee hee this drug is cool!” is infuriating! Before my diagnosis I was bullied, I was depressed, and I wondered what the hell was wrong with my and why I couldn’t do a simple task. Stim meds were literally a lifesaver for me. I have diagnosed ADHD and take 10mg extended release adderall. It does wonders for my notoriously awful study habits and work ethic but let me say this to potential users: the crashes (which occur when the drug wears off) come with (at least for me) a very noticeable wave of anxiety and scrambled train of thought that lasts for a good hour or two. ALSO, if you quit taking it after using regularly, you become noticeably more nervous and unable to drag yourself to perform more tedious work or pay attention to hardly anything. It will kick the ADHD out of you for a good seven hours, but beware of the lingering effects. It isn’t meth, but it’s still an amphetamine.
One more thing: You will forget to eat or downright not want to as long as the drug lasts. Amazing for someone who wants to lose weight but not for a barely 130 pound white dude.

I was hoping this video was taken down, that there was an update or some kind of retraction/correction for this video, but it doesn't seem to be the case. I used to really love your channel, but this video made me stop watching and unsubscribe.
This video focuses almost entirely on people taking it who don't need it and only lightly touches on how it helps people who do. It seems like it is shaming people who take it regardless of if they need it or not. While you say it was made for people who have ADHD, you don't mention that it is ok or safe for people with ADHD to use(which many peer reviewed studies show that it is).
Demonization of Adderall across the board like this and Documentaries like "Take Your Pills" is why I am still afraid to tell people I take it for my executive function disorder. It is also the kind of thinking that prevents people like me from succeeding because my parents thought ADHD was made up to sell Adderall to kids. I was diagnosed in 4th grade and if my parents didn't think it was fake, I may have at least gotten some therapy to learn ways to live with how my brain works instead of struggling how to teach myself to learn in a world that was not built for me. I was unable to do well in school because of my symptoms and I was just told I was lazy, which caused me to be very depressed and at times suicidal. I didn't have a chance to go to college because my family was poor and I "wasn't smart enough" to get any scholarships.
I have a prescription for Adderall that I NEED to do the things neurotypical people take for granted. I don't use it to get an "edge" in anything because I need it just to be on the same playing field as people who don't. Getting diagnosed AGAIN as an adult and getting treatment changed(and probably saved) my life. I can start and actually FINISH projects. I can achieve goals I set for myself and engage in hobbies that are fulfilling for me. My relationships are better. I can hold down a job and actually succeed at it rather than treading water.
I really hope you think about updating this video because stereotypes like the ones in this video have damaged my life in ways I can never fully repair. I would hate for that to extend to more kids like me suffering today that could be getting help.

After trying roughly a dozen different medications for my ADHD, Adderall (and also Adderall-XR) have proven to be the best thing to help me live effectively in my day-to-day. One big plus is that it helps me cope with my severe depression, along with concentration and energy regulation. However, I’ve started cutting back my dosage to half, and supplementing with Dexedrine, which is purely dextroamphetamine sulfate, by half of the amount cut back in my Adderall-XR. I’ve been taking these for about 9 years now since I was 15, and I’ve not really had to increase my dosage all that much since high school. I’ve found that the better the state of my mental health, the less reliant I am on my medication (to an extent) in my regular life/work.

First off, having a similar chemical structure has no direct connection to a substances pharmacological profile. Second, it is obvious how little the creator knows about millennials by calling us the adderall generation. Lastly, claiming that adderall is essentially meth is blatant sophistry and appeals to a large demographic of naive, arrogant, and simple minded know-it-alls which operate under a pretense of superiority by not using stimulants for ADHD. Stimulants like adderall have tons of empirical evidence which supports their therapeutic impact on ADHD symptoms and corresponding changes in brain structure that more closely resemble the structure of a normal brain. Genetic analyses show that there is also a set of genes which are linked to ADHD; one of which results in a dopamine reuptake transporter abnormality and a consequent lower concentration of synaptic dopamine levels. Adderall normalizes brain activity in ADHD patients and allows them to function in a competitive world. It's easy for someone without ADHD to conclude that those with it are simply undisciplined and making up an excuse for their behavior, but there are actual neuropsychological factors which are beyond their control.

Methamphetamine is a methlyated version of dextroamphetamine, making it lipid soluble. This makes it pass your blood brain barrier very quickly, and stay in your body longer. D-amphetamine also has a greater affinity to bind with dopamine receptors, while N-Methylamphetamine has a greater affinity for serotonin receptor sites.
Those who stick to therapeutic amphetamine doses are unlikely to develop tolerances. And what little neurotoxicity is created from these doses is easily remedied with simple supplements like Magnesium, Vitamin C, and anti-oxidants.

1. The dosage is good for your body or is too much or too little
2. If the person actually needs it and if the drug is going to really just be almost a placebo for them
3. If the kind they’re using is XR which will keep them wired for way longer than intended and mess up sleep habits

Their arguments against it, as well, were often quite generalized without providing any scientific evidence. It should also be noted that many science classes, especially those relating to humans (i.e. sociology and psychology), make it very clear that cultural biases are to be removed prior to observation or forming a conclusion. On top of the small sample size of college students, they don't explain how the mental facilities of each group were accounted for... such as dopamine levels being taken prior to the experiment. Giving extra dopamine to someone that already has a normal level of dopamine will have negative effects, and would many other unaccounted chemicals that make our brains function optimally.

Seratonin and Dopamine can be organically increased for extended periods of time as well. For example, exercising naturally increases the level of 'feel good' hormones, as well as positive physical contact, sexual activity (i.e. masturbation etc), and close relationships. While there might be a study for it, I haven't heard of anyone proclaim that people that stop exercising or masturbating, after long periods of time will, effectively, be unable to cope with life... unless they continue with that activity.

The artwork, if you noticed, also shows blatant biases. The person that has an increase in blood pressure looks like they just witnessed a dog getting hit, and the student taking the pills... for some reason... is downing the entire bottle (FYI... that would probably cause an overdose and kill the person). It should also be noted that STUDYING for an exam, which is where a lack of focus can really hurt, is what requires repetitive learning tasks. I can't recall a single EXAM that required complex learning skills... I really should have already done the learning (and aptitude for learning can vary extremely from one person to the next) prior to the exam, and I reinforce what I've learned by repetitively studying the learned material.

"The benefits of Adderal in academic circles is still up for debate, but the long-term effects of Adderal abuse is clear..." is extraordinarily generalized and misleading. People that take Adderal, prescribed by their doctor after testing, are not ABUSING Adderal. As he mentioned previously, people with ADHD have a shortage of the brain chemicals that Adderal helps supply, and it is thought to be genetic... not the result of poor life choices, etc. Taking Adderal lifts up the chemicals to an 'average' level, but I really don't see why it would prevent your body from continuing to respond to the stimuli that directly produces the same chemicals as well (such as exercising etc). It could be hypothesized that, through homeostasis, the body will recognize the increase in dopamine/serotonin and reduce the innate production of the chemicals, but it's not like your body will suddenly forget how to make them. Did you know, for example, that a lack of calcium in your blood (potentially caused by a lack of Vitamin D, which aids in the absorption of calcium) will initiate a process that increases the dissolving of your bones to release more calcium into your blood (research osteoclasts and osteoblasts if you want to know more about that)? Your body is fantastic and will respond to most situations to ensure optimal mental and physical health.

Upon further research, you will actually find that many of the negative side effects he lists are in cases of Adderal ABUSE. This means that the patient took the medication when not prescribed OR took a continually excessive dose that was not prescribed by their doctor. The GOAL of taking Adderal, as a patient with ADHD, is to normalize the production of specific brain chemicals. Taking too much will, obviously, have the opposite effect and will, undoubtedly, lead to negative effects in a long-term scenario.

Now, for the seemingly unprofessional and culturally biased notion that methamphetamines and Adderal (amphetamine salts), by extension, are 'destroyers of humanity.' There is one INCREDIBLY IMPORTANT FACT that separates these two drugs that are eerily similar (methamphetamines metabolizes into amphetamines but goes through a 'double' process): Adderall is a controlled substance that is created in high-tech laboratories and specifically prescribed by a certified medical professional after a typically lengthy testing period to ensure the patient would benefit from the drug. The patient is required to see their medical professional on a regular basis, and they are often encouraged to use therapeutic methods (exercise, weight loss, time management, etc.) to reduce the need for Adderall. The patient's use and dosage are quite controlled. On the other hand, methamphetamines are recreational drugs that are created in... less than opportune areas, and... due to it being 'recreational' the drug is not often taken with 'doses' and 'controlled and systematic solution to a lack of particular brain chemicals' in mind. Note that Adderall CAN and IS abused, but not everyone taking Adderall is ABUSING it. Using it as unintended and/or without a medical professional's guidance can have disastrous effects. They may be chemically similar, but their use-cases greatly separate the two.

As for the addictiveness of the drug, I can only say that there may be a large portion of that being fed by psychological aspects instead of purely biological ones. A person that takes Adderall after years of feeling stupid and lazy... finally feeling that they can be a productive member of society... able to better interact with their loved ones and properly prioritize and focus... It is easy to understand and empathize with a person when they feel like the medicine is their only hope. The same goes with other medicines that treat long-term mental quirks, like depression and anxiety.

Final thoughts... I still love AsapSCIENCE and how they take complex scientific notions and bring them to 'the masses.' However, I wonder if there are times when the fine line between entertainers and scientists gets unbalanced. Topics that have deep roots in sociology, such as circumcision and mental health, have very specific audiences when biases towards one side or another are shown. I understand that citing research papers, debating the value of particular studies, and delving into the deep information of a subject is not likely to please a wide array of the audience. I do wish that the creators at AsapSCIENCE, however, understand how influential they can be on young minds. A person out there could be suffering from ADHD and could be really helped by taking Adderall, but they may feel too ashamed or vehemently against this 'evil' drug after watching this video... where people that take Adderall are made out to be addicts that actively abuse the drug.

IF YOU BELIEVE YOU HAVE ADHD, PLEASE TALK TO A DOCTOR AND/OR THERAPIST. TALK WITH THEM ABOUT THERAPY OPTIONS AND/OR MEDICINAL OPTIONS. THEY ARE TRAINED PROFESSIONALS THAT HAVE STUDIED HOW TO BEST SOLVE A PATIENT'S NEEDS. EVERYONE IS DIFFERENT. DO NOT FEEL ASHAMED. IF YOU FEEL LIKE A MORE PRODUCTIVE AND HAPPY PERSON WHEN TAKING ADDERALL, THEN IT IS WHAT IS WORKING FOR YOU. PLEASE, FIND A MEDICAL PROFESSIONAL TO TALK TO AND, IF POSSIBLE, BLOCK OUT EGGHEADS ON THE INTERNET. I WISH YOU THE BEST IN A HAPPIER AND HEALTHIER LIFE!

Bad video, ASAP science! Amphetamine is Not the same as methamphetamine. It's like saying drinking ethanol is the same as drinking methanol. Amphetamine is not directly neurotoxic, while methamphetamine is directly neurotoxic to the brain and neurons. Amphetamine(speed) releases dopamine and norepinephrine in the brain while methamphetamine(meth) releases larger amounts of dopamine and serotonin even in small 5mg meth doses. Speed(amphetamine) only releases serotonin if you take over 60mg of it. Stacking adderall with Memantine makes it completely safe both for ADHDers and Neurotypicals. In Neurotypicals, they have a normal sizes prefrontal cortex and don't need Adderall, but get energy from it. In ADHDers, the prefrontal cortex is smaller so in order to improve executive function, Adderall is needed and it's relaxing. Adderall does not improve mean intelligence levels, only executive function. So there are plenty of cases where average intelligence or even below average intelligence Neurotypicals don't get smarter on Adderall, only faster. And also plenty of cases where gifted ADHDers struggle to function but then excel when taking Adderall, due to finally not hyperfocusing on one subject and finally blocking out external distraction thanks to Adderall. So Adderall could mean the difference between life and death for an ADHDer. Further stigmatizing Adderall and Ritalin and Memantine and Selegiline doesn't help. If you wanted to draw an analogy with anything, microdosing of LSD would've been a better pick. The study you quoted with the small sample size is also pretty poor. I understand the point you are trying to make, but as a science channel it's a bad idea to quote only studies that support the subjective narrative that you're trying to bring. We both know adderall has plenty of placebo-controlled evidence for its efficacy in both ADHD and non-ADHD people. Oh and adderall works mostly on dopamine and norepinephrine. The effect on serotonin is much less. And generation adderall... what??  Lastly, don't stigmatise the use of adderall because many ADHD patients depend on that stuff for a reasonable quality of life. This video is below par for ASAPscience standards and please refrain from letting subjective views guide the information you convey to your public.

Placebos are, by definition, a non medicine that the subject thinks is a medicine. You can't tell them it's a placebo, otherwise it wouldn't be a placebo anymore. Giving a subject medicine a then telling them it was a placebo is just stupid, because that would ruin the perception that they were taking a placebo. If you want people to think they're taking a placebo, you've got it all wrong. Any logical person who hears that they are being given a placebo will immediately know something strange is going on. To preserve the placebo effect in an experiment, you must maintain the perception in the subjects that they are consuming the actual medicine.

I'm a clinical psychologist specializing in ADHD and also have it myself. The concerns about abuse and addiction with adderall in non ADHD individuals needs attention, as the abuse in students is rampant (I have taught in University as well). However, this video has a lot of misleading info and a few things border on propaganda:

1. Adderall and other stimulant medications should only be taken by those who have been formally (via neuropsych testing) diagnosed with ADHD.
2. The dose makes the poison. Just because they're both "Amphetamine" does not mean "it's just like meth!" Dose size/frequency and delivery method matter.
3. Adderall and other stimulant medications have been shown to be effective and safe for long term use in over 400 large scale clinical studies going back way before there were brand names for these drugs (some 75 years). This includes data showing it works better than placebo, although the placebo effect shown in the video is important for those that use it as a study aid.
4. Stigma, misunderstanding, myths, and disbelief of individuals with ADHD is rampant, even among medical and mental health professionals, and this type of myth and misinformation leads some to not get beneficial treatment.
5. Those looking for detailed empirical research about ADHD and medication should seek the books by Dr. Russel Barkley, the leading expert in the world on the topic.

P.S. Non-stimulant alternatives also exist for treatment for those that are intersted, including Strattera and Gaunfacine.

I’m really glad AsapScience posted this!! Adderall is highly addictive and I feel like not a lot of people understand what pharmaceutical meds do to your brain.
I was diagnosed with type 2 ADHD when I was 6. I spent the next 15yrs on and off of ADHD meds before subsequently switching to non-pharmaceutical treatment. Adderall was the hardest to get over. When I was first prescribed it, my recommended dosage was 20mg (which is absolutely absurd to me). 20mg was 4x the amount of what I needed! The first time I took the full dosage, I stayed up for 36hrs and couldn’t eat. I really only needed about 5mg, so I started there. I used to break up my tablets into 4, but then I started to feel groggy and irritable all the time so I upped the dosage to 10mg, then 15, 20, 30...eventually I was crushing 60mg a day (3x what my initial prescribed amount was). It was awful! I became overly aggressive and emotional. If I went too long or didn’t take enough Adderall, I’d experience huge depression crashes. I also lost 15lbs from not eating enough, but my body started over producing Cortisol because I was too stressed so I had all this hanging fat that developed from losing weight too quickly in an unhealthy way. Additionally, my heart would race so fast from excessive use that I had started to develop heart palpitations. So eventually, in the middle of a huge slump, I decided I needed to stop taking Adderall because I was addicted and it was physically hurting me (btw Adderall is awful for your liver— prolonged use can cause a ton of complications). So I quit and haven’t touched it in almost a year now, I highly recommend if you have ADHD— seek alternative remedies! There’s a lot of natural based things (such as increased B12 intake, meditation, etc) that help so much more and allow you to feel like yourself still!

Oxygen is more similar to ozone than amphetamine is to methamphetamine. Oxygen is essential to life, ozone is deadly. However, the comparison is meaningless, and saying oxygen is like ozone in a discussion of its physiology is misleading. Likewise, the way methamphetamine is discussed in this video is similarly shameful. The sentiment, "Amphetamine is bad because methamphetamine is bad!" isn't at all scientific and potentially harmful. Regardless, methamphetamine itself isn't inherently bad and has numerous medical applications. Levomethamphetamine, for example, is available over-the-counter as a nasal decongestant. The video takes advantage of the emotional and unscientific "meth is evil" meme to push its thesis rather than sticking to scientific evidence.

Last I checked, this is AsapSCIENCE, not AsapSENSATIONALISM.

(Maybe I'm being a little too harsh with that statement as, aside from the emotionally exploitive methamphetamine comparisons, the science presented in the rest of the video is pretty solid. I just can't help but feel angry about obvious sophistry in an otherwise coherent video.)

The great irony of drugs is that they are invented to improve our lives but then the best ones are prohibited so we can't improve our lives with them. This is because the better the drug the more addicting its use or dangerous its misuse. We as a society make blanket laws taking away the choice in order to protect those biologically susceptible to problematic behavior such as drug addiction and misuse. However, as individuals, we may not be a risk. I've never been one to develop addictions or habits and I generally like a clear sober mind. When used correctly, certain drugs can have an overwhelmingly positive effect on a person's life.
Percocets completely remove chronic nerve pain whereas safer (still prescription) drugs merely lightly dull it. Percocets isn't something you want to take frequently but the option should be there, maybe get one day free of the pain like normal people are supposed to be all the time. Cocaine has its practical application as well, though my experience is very limited. Low energy levels, a lot of work to do, some social anxiety, and practicing performer? It might help. Again, not an everyday thing but it has its practical application. Plus drugs can make for a great time recreationally and socially, but just as many people become terrible with recreational use as well. It's not going to make a trouble person less trouble.

Why assume that the effects of amphetamines is identical are someone without adhd and someone with adhd?

Compare adderal to caffeine for a moment. If you were tired or trying to wake up, coffee would help you focus and be productive. If you were already focused and amped, (more) caffeine might make you jittery and scattered. Similarly, someone without ADHD (who can already focus) who then takes an amphetamine often becomes frantic, anxious, and erratic. Such does no lend itself to focus. Someone with ADHD who then takes his/her medication will often become more relaxed has an increased ability to direct one's time and focus.

If you normally drink one cup of coffee to wake up (i.e. hdhd, take medicine to function as everyone else does), then a second cup would make you antsy (i.e. no hdhd, take medicine and become antsy).

This is an EXTREMELY biased video, coming from the point of view of someone who is most likely neurotypical. I was diagnosed with ADHD at 27, and one of my biggest regrets is that I didn’t seek treatment sooner. I graduated from college, by some grace of God, but when I entered the field of mental health case management, my cognitive deficits really became apparent. I believed that I was stupid, I had cripplingly low self-worth, and I would mentally punish myself and self-injure, because I just could not understand why everyone around me was able to get their work done on time and  how they were able to get so much accomplished. I started get in trouble for my work performance, and after speaking with my psychiatrist, he referred me for ADHD testing. The results made it glaringly obvious that I have ADHD, and to boot, the psychologist who performed the testing informed me that my IQ is in the average to above average range. I started receiving stimulant treatment from my psychiatrist, in the form of, surprise!, Adderall, and my world has done a complete 360. There is no magical bullet; I still have to make a concentrated effort to avoid situations that can get me off track, like overhearing and wanting to join in on an interesting conversation between coworkers when I have things to do, but Adderall gives me the ability to DECIDE not to get distracted. With any medication, there can be side effects, such as addiction, but it’s a question of quality of life. And addiction involves so many factors, as not everyone who takes the same substance will develop an addiction. Also, I have never, ever heard any generation called the “Adderall Generation,” and my friends and coworkers are mental health and medical providers.

I wish videos like this would actually clarify and emphasize that the use of prescribed, low dosages for appropriately diagnosed ADHD can be incredibly important and helpful for that person's ability to function normally or have a chance at getting a college degree (LITERALLY ONLY 5% OF COLLLEGE STUDENTS WITH ADHD WILL GRADUATE ) and getting into the middle class. The video seemed to touch lightly on the idea that ADHD brains are different, but still leaves a sort of idea that the use of appropriately prescribed adderall might be the same thing as recreational meth use.

The thing that bugs me the most as a person who takes adderall is the idea that it's self-indulgent drug abuse, or "cheating" to have an advantage over everyone else and "get straight A's" while in reality the average goddamn person takes for granted an ability to focus and ignore distractions on a daily basis better than probably most people with ADHD have even on medication.

That doesn't even take into account that ADHD commonly co-occurs with other conditions such as learning disorders, severe insomnia, or depression and anxiety, so as a person with ADHD even if you can manage to treat the attention lapses, distractibility, forgetfulness, and restlessness, you are still often left with things like sleep deprivation, mental fog, abnormally slow processing of information, struggling to understand directions, low motivation, difficulty with organization, learning disabilites, emotional disregulation, and even more fun problems to have.

All while people don't believe you really have a disorder and think your use of medication is a fun meth habit to have an unfair advantage in school.

I have been taking Adderall XR since my sophomore year of college. The point I realized I probably had ADHD was when even if I was in the quiet study room and trying to focus on studying my mind just kept wandering. After I started taking one thing I learned is that it doesn't make you want to study, it just made me able to. I still needed the discipline to do it, and when I did try to study I found I was able to. It has been a miracle drug for me but I think a big danger is taking it without the discipline to focus on tasks you should be doing. It increases the chemicals in your brain that make you feel rewarded for doing things, so while on it whatever you do is going to be entertaining. If you slack off while on it it's just that much worse than slacking off while not on it.

Modafinil is an excellent alternative.  It's a central nervous-system stimulant and is NOT an amphetamine.  It makes you more alert and you focus better.  Best not to take it after 4PM or it will keep you uip late!  It used to be prescribed to Air Force pilots to help them stay awake an alert on long missions and is now used to treat narcolepsy.  There are no downsides to occasional use in my experience.  I limit myself to 1 a week or less so take that as you will.  It's also cheaper than adderall for those buying illegitimately but since it's MUCH less known and prescriptions aren't signed off on the daily it can be a bit harder to find.
